MSJC: Temecula hoping colleges take root in old City Hall/NCTimes

September 28th, 2012

FYI

http://www.nctimes.com/news/local/temecula/temecula-city-hoping-colleges-take-root-in-old-city-hall/article_a6c8ff74-eb9e-59a0-a5e8-58ddec30415c.html?oCampaign=email

“Temcula officials say the city is talking to three colleges—-Cal State San Marcos, Mt. San Jacinito College and San Diego State University—-about setting up in the 30,000 square foot facility on Business Park Drive, the old City Hall Building.”

Blog:

As a trustee at MSJC, I am uninformed re these discussions.  This is symptomatic as to the non-transparency of the MSJC current administration and two elected board members who control the majority.

The November election in Trustee/Area 5 (Temecula/Murrieta) is critical for new transparency on the board of trustees at MSJC.

Leasing and/or rental of facilities by community colleges is not the mindset of higher education in California. Such campus sites CANNOT be approved as “state approved centers” and thus do not qualify for capital construction dollars or increases in operational dollars/growth of FTES.  However, due to current state budget restrictions, the state is not honoring growth in FTES for new facilities due to workload reductions in FTES in which hundreds of class sections have been cut and student access to educational opportunity greatly compromised.

California Community Colleges Board of Governors Approves System-wide Enrollment Priorities to Increase Student Success

September 11th, 2012

FYI

“New students who have completed college orientation, assessment and developed education plans as well as continuing students in good academic standing who have not exceeded 100 units will now have priority over students who do not meet these criteria.”

http://californiacommunitycolleges.cccco.edu/Portals/0/DocDownloads/PressReleases/SEP2012/PRESS_RELEASE_BOGPRIORITY_091012x_FINAL.pdf

Blog:

100 Units?  Transfer to UC/CSU requires 60 units.

It would seem best that those students with +60 units should be last to register.   Doing such would increase access for new students who are just seeking to pursue an undergraduate opportunity to transfer.  If they haven’t figured out yet how to transfer, its quite possible they never will.  Shouldn’t counselors be carefully monitoring/managing those students with +60 units to ensure transfer?  Are they?

Hemet PD, MSJC team up for internship program/PE

September 10th, 2012

FYI

http://blog.pe.com/hemet/2012/09/08/hemet-pd-msjc-team-up-for-internship-program/

“Hemet PD and MSJC announced this week that they are teaming up for a PD internship program.

“Hemet PD will be hosting two interns during the fall 2012 semester.  The internship is a semester class requiring students to work 180 hours of volunteer service.  The students who complete the internship will receive three units of college credit.”

Blog:

This discussion never took place with the Board of Trustees.  Which agency is liable in case of an accident during the 180 hours of “volunteer service”?  In my opinion, this issue should have been brought to the full board for open discussion and discovery PRIOR to an administrative decision.

This is exactly what’s wrong with MSJC and it’s administrative process.  The BOT is left out!

MSJC/Menifee to kick off another school year/NCTimes

August 18th, 2012

http://www.nctimes.com/news/local/menifee/menifee-msjc-to-kick-off-another-school-year-monday/article_a1d286d9-61fe-5a4d-a9be-f10ee5351ae5.html?oCampaign=email

“MSJC will open its doors to nearly 15,000 students on Monday, and despite all the budget cuts in recent years there is a little good news on the Menifee Valley Campus.  A new $9.6 million Social Sciences and Humanities Building is open and will be formally dedicated Sept. 14th.  The building was built with capital improvement funds approved by the state several years ago.”

“Class have been downsized because most teaching positions opened by attrition have gone unfilled.  The school’s part-time faculty has been drastically cut.”

Blog:

This is a $9.6 million dollar building built without local bonds at NO cost to local taxpayers.   The entire MVC has been built this way by qualifying at the state level based upon population and participation rates.

According to district apportionment reports, MSJC served the same number of FTES (9688) in 2006/07 as it is served in 2011/12.  The difference in funding was $41 million base funding in 2006/07 vs. $49 million in base funding this past year.  An $8 million dollars increase serving the same number of FTES as in 06/07. How is that additional $8 million being allocated now?

Administrative salaries/levels have increased since 06/07. The district should consider cuts in administration in order to restore the hundreds of class sections once taught by part-time faculty and provide increased access to our students.  Cutting class sections (enrollment management) should not be the only solution to the state’s budget crisis.

The Chronicle/New Analysis/Virginia and Penn State Boards showed Perils of Secrecy

August 17th, 2012

FYI

http://chronicle.com/article/VirginiaPenn-State-Boards/133751/?cid=at&utm_source=at&utm_medium=en

“In both instances, key decision makers appear to have concluded that shielding details from the public would best protect the reputations of individuals and institutions.  The opposite proved true.”

“One of the clear takeaways from these conversations is that transparency, while sometimes temporarily painful, is preferable in the long run.  If these situations showed us anything, it is that the truth will come out, and a board is better positioned to deal with uncomfortable truths when they are openly confronted from the beginning.”

Blog:

“The truth will come out”.  In my opinion, MSJC has suffered from non-transparency for quite sometime. Elected officials should not have to make public record act requests to attain information re the agency they serve.  Unfortunately, it happens.

The Brown Act clearly states:  “The people of this State do not yield their sovereignty to the agencies which serve them.   The people do not give their public servants the right to decide what is good for the people to know and what is not good for them to know.”

http://codes.lp.findlaw.com/cacode/GOV/1/5/d2/1/9/s54950
